data.title: Mapping Diversity
data.meta_description: Mapping Diversity is a platform for discovering key facts about diversity and representation in street names across Europe.
data.text:
Mapping Diversity is a platform for discovering key facts about diversity and representation in street names across Europe, and to spark a debate about who is missing from our urban spaces.

We looked at the names of 155,468 streets across 32 major European cities, located in 19 different countries. More than 90% of the streets named after individuals are dedicated to white men. Where did all the other inhabitants of Europe end up? The lack of diversity in toponymy speaks volumes about our past and contributes to shaping Europeâs present and future.

Explore your city

Browse European capitals

Browse by country

Who is honored by our streets?

Examining the lack of representation in street names across Europe

Take a stroll through any major European city and you'll notice a trend in the names of its streets. They typically honour the same type of people: white men who were either wealthy, influential, or both. It's a subtle yet powerful reminder of who our society values, or has valued, and who it doesn't. This platform explores the lack of diversity in the street names of 32 cities from 19 different European countries, monitoring a total of 56,852 streets named after an individual. The overall result already hints at the problem: only 9% of these are named after a woman, that is 5,247.

Behind these numbers there is broad variability between cities, although none come close to any kind of gender equality in street names. Stockholm tops the ranking with 19.5% of its streets named after women, followed by Madrid (18.7%) and Sevilla (17.2%). Debrecen, with 2.7%, has the lowest share of streets honouring women, at least among the cities monitored so far. It sits at the bottom of the ranking, preceded by Prague (4.3%) and Athens (4.5%).

Lack of diversity in street names speaks of our past, but talks to our future

The preponderance of male figures in our streets is not only evidence of a historical and cultural fact, but also a force, subliminal but constant, that contributes to perpetuating the marginalization of female contributions in history, art, culture, or the sciences. Women honoured by European street names may be few and far between, but who are they? What are the characteristics of those who are visible, and who remains invisible?

Women's legacies in European cities

Overall, the 32 different cities under consideration honour 3,088 unique women from a variety of backgrounds. The Virgin Mary is the most frequent name, with 369 street dedications, in 26 of the 32 cities. For comparison, the most popular man, Peter, has 52 street dedications. The second most common female street name is also religious: Saint Anne, after whom 37 streets in 20 different cities are named.

The most popular women figures

While Virgin Mary and Saint Anne are the most frequent women's names in the cities surveyed, the majority of streets named after a woman do not honour a religious person. Instead, about half of such streets are named after women who made significant contributions in the field of culture, science and arts, with writer being the most common profession. However, there are differences between cities, particularly with respect to the prevalence of religious names.

Geographically, European cities tend to honour women who... well, unsurprisingly were born in Europe! There are however a few exceptions to this trend, for example in the case of biblical and religious figures.

The majority of women with a street dedication belong to late modern history, mostly to the 19th and 20th century. The most recent figure with street dedications in multiple countries is Anna Politkovskaya, the Russian journalist and activist murdered in 2006, with streets named after her in Prague, Paris, and Rome.

While changing street names alone may not be sufficient for creating a more equitable society, we cannot overlook the stereotypes and collective perceptions that are reinforced when 90.2% of street names are dedicated to men. Below you find the list of all the women with a street dedication in the 32 monitored cities. Who are the women who remain largely invisible in our public spaces?

Who were these women?

While gender equality is a complex issue that extends beyond just the names of our streets, the symbolic power of toponymy cannot be ignored. As we navigate through public spaces, we internalise the values and priorities that our community has chosen to uphold. Unfortunately, the current gender gap in street names is staggering, and this issue must be addressed. One way to make progress is to call upon the toponymy commissions of our cities to recognize this problem and take action to ensure that underrepresented figures and their invaluable contributions are acknowledged in our urban space. To learn more about the specific situation in each European city, be sure to read EDJNet's in-depth stories linked below.

Read our in-depth stories

Browse the data

Mapping Diversity is a project coordinated by OBC Transeuropa for the European Data Journalism Network, first published in March 2023. A pilot project on Italy was published in 2021.

Concept and editorial coordination: Giorgio Comai, Lorenzo Ferrari

Data collection and analysis: Giorgio Comai, Ornaldo Gjergji, Alice Corona

Design and development: Sheldon.studio

Homepage data storytelling: Alice Corona

The following members of the European Data Journalism Network contributed to the data collection: OBC Transeuropa, BiQdata/Gazeta Wyborcza, Denik Referendum, Divergente, El Orden Mundial, EUrologus/HVG, iMEdD, Voxeurop.

Street names and geographic data: © OpenStreetMap contributors, released under ODbL; © EuroGeographics for the administrative boundaries.

Information from Wikidata is available under a CC0-public domain licence.

To the extent that is possible, all remaining data and contents are released by EDJNet under a CC BY 4.0 licence.
